newsitem.title: NORWAY: Fokus proposes merger with BnB.
newsitem.headline: Fokus proposes merger with BnB.

text.p: Norway's fourth largest bank, Fokus Bank ASA, said on Tuesday it had proposed a merger with Bolig og Naeringsbanken, a Trondheim-based bank.
Fokus proposed an exchange ratio of 3.3 shares in Fokus Bank for each share in BNB, also known as BNbank, but with 20 percent of the consideration paid in cash.
Based on Fokus' share price on Monday of 58.50 crowns, the exchange ratio equals a price on BNbank of 179.85 crowns per share and 10 crowns in dividend, Fokus said in a statement.
BNbank closed at 167 crowns on Monday on the Oslo Bourse.
"Fokus Bank has today sent a letter to the Board of Directors in BNbank proposing a merger between the two banks," the statement said.
It said the joint bank would have total assets of about 60 billion crowns and be a leader in targeted regions.
With BNbank, Fokus would confirm its position as fourth largest bank in Norway. It is also the third largest commercial bank.
"The merger will result in substantial cost and income synergies and a broader shareholder base with a large Norwegian component," Trondheim-based Fokus said.
"Headquartered in Trondheim, the merged unit will have a large customer base to which it will be able to offer a broad range of financial solutions," it said.

"Fokus Bank is seeking a friendly, negotiated merger between equal parties. BNbank will be a vital part of the merger company's operation. The proposal means that BNbank's operation will be carried on after the merger, as a subsidiary of Fokus Bank," the statement said.

Fokus last month said 1996 pre-tax operating profits rose 7.7 percent to 462 million crowns from a year earlier thanks to successful regional banking which emphasizes local expertise and decentralised authorities.
Managing Director Bjarne Borgersen at the time also said the entire banking industry faced considerable competitive challenges, which implicated changes and restructuring.
